body:
> My question is, from a user experience point of view, is it useful for users to have that many tokens with different thresholds in just one interface? Which is the general use case? Proposers are going to ask for that different range of tokens or just one (probably DAI?).

I know that at the hackathon we had leaned towards supporting multiple assets, but I think the general use case is probably that one token/currency will be used for proposals. And in the event that an org would support multiple assets, it probably would be a relatively small list, eg DAI and Organization Tokens. 

> We can also cover the general use case by installing the conviction voting many times, and specify on each of them the token it is going to be requested (similar to the Token Manager app).

Agreed, if we decide to just support one token (set at initialization), it would be reasonable to install multiple instances of the app. 

> Does it make sense, or do you prefer a single app with an integrated interface for managing all the tokens? 

I'm comfortable with simplifying things (both technically and from a UX perspective) by choosing to only support a single asset for each instance of conviction voting. 👍
This issue was solved on d7919c540989cded9b2e1e76fff87521f111f2a0.
It's mostly done. Closing in favor of #10 and #14.
Most of it has been done in the refactor. Closing in favor of #16 and #17 .

How do we ensure this content gets pinned? This was a significant pain point when we were working on https://github.com/1hive/airdrop-app at Ethdenver 

It looks like with the wiki app the user has to be running ipfs locally, it would be nice if this was not the case as I don't think this is common for most users (even though it would be nice if that were the case 😅). 

There seems to also be some work towards smart contract being discussed here that might be relevant: https://forum.aragon.org/t/aragon-network-ipfs-pinning/824

I'm not sure I like the use of "Has passed" here since its not really a definite state, it currently is passed the threshold that allows it to be executed, but it may not be in the future. 

For example we could have a situation where funds are added to the vault, which lowers the threshold on many proposals making them all eligible to be executed, after executing the first one there is less funds available and the other proposals are no longer at threshold. 

I think the status should be something like "Can be executed", and the call to action on the button should probably be "Execute proposal". 

I don't think enact is the right word as it typically refers to "making something into law" which doesn't quite fit the action of transferring funds. (I know this is what is used in the current voting app, but I think it ought to not be used their either... 🙈)

Unfortunately I think that is not possible. As you can see in the conviction formula ![y_{i+1}=x+\alpha%20y_{i}](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?y_{i+1}=x+\alpha%20y_{i}), we calculate conviction (![y_{i+1}](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?y_{i+1})) from last conviction (![y_{i}](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?y_{i})) and the tokens staked on a certain time  (![x](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?x)). On #16 what we do is to avoid a loop to calculate conviction for each block if the stake is constant (which saves a lot of gas), but when somebody stakes or withdraws, we have to plug the result of the last formula into the ![y_{i}](https://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?y_{i}) of a new one that uses the new amount of tokens staked.

This is why we save the last conviction and last block on each stake and withdraw, because if we calculate the total conviction on the last step, we would need to loop over all stakes and withdraws, being vulnerable to an out of gas attack.

But please, if you see any other possible improvement in the code tell me.
Ah I see, apologies for not looking deep enough. Otherwise it looks great man! Will keep an eye on your progress.

I think perhaps we should take a different tact on this and start with why it is important to have a canceled state? is this to clean up the view? if things are paginated and things that are old and lack any conviction are showed last, is there a need to cancel them at all? 

Is there a technical (or UX reason) why having a canceled state is important?

After writing this I changed my mind. I think an even simpler solution is to use `t=77` when `t>77`, so we cap conviction on what it reaches during its first 77 units of time from the last stake or withdrawal.

On the other hand, we are still looking for a better solidity function to avoid all that problem.

If we want to order the proposals by conviction achieved, we have to calculate it for all of them. Having too many stale proposals may make this process slower, but not much slower, so I don't think it's a technical requirement to close proposals.

Regarding UX reasons, I think that many proposals can be outdated in a short period of time because they have a deadline, such as "Preparing an Aragon event during the Devcon". After the Devcon, this proposal have not any more sense, so maybe we have to conceive Conviction Voting for proposals that can be done at any time, such as the development of an app / DAO (such as conviction voting or CRDAO), or the direction a project should take (such as going for an Arachain).

I would issue the first conviction voting version without the cancelling option and see what happens. We don't have to [optimize prematurely](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Program_optimization#When_to_optimize), and we can always add this feature later.

However, I would keep this issue active in order to get more feedback from the rest of the community.
What are your thoughts on that @lkngtn?
Agree that the trend should indicate the future direction, it allows people to know if conviction is accumulating or dissipating on the proposal.
Changes added in fce96f0bc22d0a1683befeda30492dbc6c3d9dcc
Fixed in fce96f0bc22d0a1683befeda30492dbc6c3d9dcc.
I have found the graph to be quite useful in explaining what is happening, but agree that without context it could seem quite unintuitive and complex.

Cool! 
Noticed i could have gotten the request Token from the contract itself. My bad there.

Should we merge?
Merged :tada:!
I squashed and merged manually the code on: https://github.com/1Hive/conviction-voting-app/commit/b40983d133a04a2f7468d5779ef150de20763e05

Folks at Commons Stack may have already thought on a solution, as they post on [their blog](https://medium.com/giveth/conviction-voting-a-novel-continuous-decision-making-alternative-to-governance-aa746cfb9475):

> When a member joins the community, they will be requested to assert percentages of their preference towards existing proposals, adding up to 100% in total. Using something like the ERC-888 token standard, we can allow tokens to be automatically asserted towards proposals, without affecting token liquidity with staking locks. Since your preferences are expressed as a percentage of your token holdings, any change to your token holdings (through buying or selling) automatically updates the weight of your preference.

I still have to check out [ERC-888: The Multidimensional Token Standard](https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/888), and see how we can use it in this case.

I think this solution won't work (or will have significant trade-offs) because even if the weight represents a percentage, you are forced to tabulate conviction all at once when executing the proposal since you don't have any guarantees about the balances staked to a proposal over time. 

if you tabulate conviction all at once at the end, then you force the person doing the tabulation to pay for all of the gas and also introduce issues where either we can only take the top staked amounts and include that (to limit the number of addresses we evaluate) or potentially hit out of gas errors. 

Atleast that is my understanding of the issue at this time, is that not the case with the approach you are referencing?

In 68a49ed I implement an alternative implementation to ETHParis' solidity implementation for conviction formula, which sets a constant scaling factor of instead of an exponential :

The `+2^127` at the end is used for rounding. The tests I've written show that the formula maintains the relative error below the 0.1% for a wide variety of parameters.
did anybody have `RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded` when `npx truffle test`?

I created a first test (here https://github.com/1Hive/conviction-voting-app/commit/608479861ef00dd1719a2e373597acd43a8ba30c) so it may be easier to add new ones now.

To run them it is better to use `npm test`, because it deploys a test ganache network, and takes care of everything.
Yeah, I wanted to add some tests, but I still get `RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded` with a  use of `npm test`.
I'm not sure, but it may be because of the node version. Which one are you using? The one that is pretty well supported by aragon-cli is `v10.17.0`.
Alright, it was because of node version, thanks a lot!

did I get right, that tests require time increase? or you mean something else by this?
```
// on time
```

Yes, it means to execute after a certain number of blocks. I think this [can be achieved](https://medium.com/edgefund/time-travelling-truffle-tests-f581c1964687) with the `evm_mine` function.

On the other hand, stake token, funds token and vault should also be mocked (because now the app is initialized with them set at `0x0`).

alright, so it's about number of block, not timestamp. It means that for tests we should increase block number for x10 (20, 50 e.t.c) times, doesn't it?  

do you mean `requestedToken` by `TKN`?
